articles.headline: Critic of Japan’s Central Bank Is Now Its Leader
articles.snippet: Haruhiko Kuroda, a Finance Ministry veteran and lover of Greek philosophy, has been charged with turning around an institution reviled for its monetary policy.
articles.abstract: Haruhiko Kuroda, a Finance Ministry veteran and lover of Greek philosophy, has been charged with turning around an institution reviled for its monetary policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the late 1990s, in the thick of the Asian financial crisis, a top Japanese Finance Ministry official turned to his protégé and found him engrossed not in policy documents, but in a chunky volume of the works of Aristotle.

articles.headline: Hidden Numbers Make Banks Even Bigger
articles.snippet: New accounting rules will force better disclosure of assets and liabilities of American banks that trade heavily in derivatives.
articles.abstract: New accounting rules will force better disclosure of assets and liabilities of American banks that trade heavily in derivatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a simple question. How big is that bank?

articles.headline: Fed Rebukes Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase Over Capital Plans
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said Goldman and JPMorgan would need to resubmit their proposals to pay out billions of dollars to shareholders, citing weaknesses in their capital plans.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said Goldman and JPMorgan would need to resubmit their proposals to pay out billions of dollars to shareholders, citing weaknesses in their capital plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, the Wall Street giants that emerged from the financial crisis in a position of strength, are now facing questions about their ability to withstand future market shocks.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Faulted on Controls and Disclosure in Trading Loss
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase ignored internal controls and manipulated documents, as the nation’s biggest bank racked up trading losses last year, Senate investigators say.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase ignored internal controls and manipulated documents, as the nation’s biggest bank racked up trading losses last year, Senate investigators say.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s biggest bank, ignored internal controls and manipulated documents as it racked up trading losses last year, while its influential chief executive, Jamie Dimon, briefly withheld some information from regulators, a new Senate report says.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Thomson Reuters Editor Is Charged in Hacking of News Site
articles.snippet: Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old social media editor, was charged with assisting the hacking collective Anonymous in an attack on The Los Angeles Times Web site.
articles.abstract: Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old social media editor, was charged with assisting the hacking collective Anonymous in an attack on The Los Angeles Times Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. | Updated Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old deputy social media editor at Thomson Reuters, has been charged with assisting the hacking collective Anonymous in an attack on the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, the Justice Department said Thursday.

articles.headline: Samsung Introduces New Galaxy Phone
articles.snippet: Increasing the stakes in the smartphone battle, the South Korean manufacturer showed off the Galaxy S IV, the latest version of its flagship device.
articles.abstract: Increasing the stakes in the smartphone battle, the South Korean manufacturer showed off the Galaxy S IV, the latest version of its flagship device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics is the world leader in smartphone sales, besting Apple in many countries. Now Samsung of South Korea is stepping up its challenge to Apple, bringing the battle to its rival’s home turf.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Republicans Are Divided on Proper Role for U.S. Abroad
articles.snippet: A new generation of Republican leaders is questioning the approach of an aggressive use of American power abroad as a policy imperative and a political advantage.
articles.abstract: A new generation of Republican leaders is questioning the approach of an aggressive use of American power abroad as a policy imperative and a political advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than three decades, the Republican Party brand has been deeply tied to a worldview in which the aggressive use of American power abroad is both a policy imperative and a political advantage.

articles.headline: In Syrian Clash Over ‘Death Highway,’ a Bitterly Personal War
articles.snippet: A battle for a stretch of northern road that government forces still risk using pits a conventional arsenal against fighters armed with faith as much as weapons.
articles.abstract: A battle for a stretch of northern road that government forces still risk using pits a conventional arsenal against fighters armed with faith as much as weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEESH, Syria — The Islamic fighters peered through rifle scopes and machine-gun sights at the remains of a Syrian military convoy disabled on the highway several hundred yards away. They were peppering President Bashar al-Assad’s soldiers with gunfire, trying to prevent their escape.

articles.headline: Younger Generations Lag Parents in Wealth-Building
articles.snippet: A study finds that younger working adults are not doing better financially than the previous generation.
articles.abstract: A study finds that younger working adults are not doing better financially than the previous generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pearl Brady has a stable job with good benefits and holds two degrees, a bachelor’s and a master’s. But despite her best efforts, she has no savings, and worries that it will be years before she manages to start putting away money for a house, children and eventually retirement.

articles.headline: Snub of Reformers’ Choice Seen Before Pope’s Anointing
articles.snippet: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.
articles.abstract: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The choice of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio as pope was so surprising, the Italian bishops sent out an e-mail congratulating the wrong man. His profile was so low that he was barely mentioned by the feverish handicappers and Vaticanologists who make their living scrutinizing the Holy See. But the Argentine emerged from the conclave a swiftly anointed Pope Francis on Wednesday evening, barely 28 hours after it began.

articles.headline: Economy Rolls Along, Despite Cuts and Taxes
articles.snippet: Analysts expected that a federal austerity plan would be a drag on growth, but most recent indicators show the economy is strengthening.
articles.abstract: Analysts expected that a federal austerity plan would be a drag on growth, but most recent indicators show the economy is strengthening.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy appears to be bucking the headwinds from Washington, buoyed by healthy business activity and resilient consumers.
